Microsoft Says Password Expiry Makes You Less Secure

Why forcing password changes every 90 days actually hurts your security

December 20, 2024 3 min read Beginner
Security Best Practices

My Takeaway Four years later, still secure

I remember about 3 years ago my manager tapped me on the shoulder and said "You know expiring your password is actually less secure than just having a really strong password" and I noticed that this was the first place I ever worked at that didn't have a password expiration period. I was blown away and for the next 4 years working here I have never changed my password.

The Mind-Blowing Revelation

That conversation completely changed how I thought about password security. For years, I'd been conditioned to believe that forcing password changes every 90 days was a security best practice. Every company I'd worked for had some version of this policy - "Passwords expire every 90 days" or "You must change your password quarterly."

But here I was, at a company that didn't force password changes at all. And according to my manager, this was actually more secure. My mind was blown.

Why Password Expiry Backfires

It turns out that Microsoft's research team has been saying this for years. When you force people to change passwords frequently, they do predictable things:

  • Use patterns like Password1, Password2, Password3
  • Make minimal changes like MyPassword â†’ MyPassw0rd
  • Write passwords down because they're hard to remember
  • Use the same password across multiple accounts

Microsoft found that users forced to change passwords every 90 days are 2.5 times more likely to use weaker passwords than users who aren't forced to change them regularly.

The logic is simple: if an attacker gets your password, they use it immediately. They don't wait around for 90 days. And if they can't get in right away, they move on to other targets.

What Actually Works

Instead of forcing password changes, focus on:

  • Strong passwords from the start - 12+ characters, unique for each account
  • Multi-factor authentication (MFA) - Microsoft found this blocks 99.9% of attacks
  • Monitoring for compromised passwords - change only when there's evidence of breach
  • User education - teach people about password security best practices

My Takeaway

Four years later, I still haven't changed my password at that company. And you know what? I feel more secure than I ever did at places that forced quarterly changes.

Sometimes the best security practices are the ones that work with human nature, not against it. A strong password that never changes is better than weak passwords that change every 90 days.

What do you think? Have you worked somewhere that doesn't force password changes?
